misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required by the problem. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process these inputs, check each number for evenness using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers.
Uses double variables and an acceleration formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing integers.
No loop to iterate over 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers or accumulator for their sum.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different textbook-style problem about computing average acceleration, leading them to ignore the actual requirements (5 integers, sum of evens).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required inputs, the required processing (loop + even check), and the required output. Before coding, outline the steps: read 5 integers, loop through them, if a number is even add it to sum, then print the sum.
related_concepts: Looping over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variable names, formula, and output message) clearly targets an average acceleration problem rather than the required sum-of-evens task.

evidence.note: The entire main method is dedicated to an average-acceleration calculation with three double inputs and no loop, instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Goal
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code intended for a different problem (calculating average acceleration, likely from a physics or prior programming assignment) instead of the required task (finding the sum of even numbers among 5 user inputs). This results in a complete failure to meet any of the rubric requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this program fulfills the requirements for Q1, possibly due to submission error or confusion between assignments.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires initializing a sum accumulator, using a loop to read exactly 5 integer inputs, and employing conditional logic (modulo operator) to include only even numbers in the sum.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double variables instead of 5 integers
Calculates acceleration using a kinematic formula
No loop structure present
Missing modulo operator (%) logic
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly identify or implement the required algorithm specified in the prompt/rubric. The student solved an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q1, 'Sum of Even Numbers,' and structure your code to read five inputs and use a loop and an 'if' statement with the % operator to process them correctly.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code variables (v0, v1, t, acceleration) and the calculation formula ((v1 - v0) / t) unambiguously point to an average acceleration calculation, entirely unrelated to finding the sum of even numbers.

evidence.note: The core logic of the submitted program calculates acceleration using inputs v0, v1, and t, confirming the student solved the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has fundamentally misunderstood the assignment. Instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, they wrote a completely different program that calculates acceleration from three physics variables (v0, v1, and t).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t, which suggests they may have worked on a different assignment or misread the requirements entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum. For the sample input '3 8 2 7 4', the even numbers are 8, 2, and 4, which sum to 14.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present
No conditional check for even numbers
Program implements physics acceleration formula instead of even number sum
Output message completely different from requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements. The student may have copied code from a different problem or failed to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. The program needs to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Use a loop to process each number, (3) Check if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) Sum only the even numbers, and (5) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence because the submitted code is a completely different program solving a different problem. There is no overlap between the requirements (sum of even numbers from 5 integers) and the implementation (calculate acceleration from 3 physics variables). This is not a partial attempt at the correct solution; it is an entirely different solution.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as required by the problem
Implements physics acceleration formula instead of summing even numbers
Output is about acceleration, not the sum of even numbers as required
Entire program solves a different problem (physics acceleration) rather than the assigned task (sum of even numbers)

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted problem requirements (implemented different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers, so none of the required problem logic (loop over 5 integers, even check, accumulation) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads initial velocity v0, final velocity v1, and time t, then compute and print the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process these 5 inputs, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and finally print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'.
Inputs are stored in double variables v0, v1, and t rather than iterating over 5 integer values.
There is no loop to read or process 5 numbers.
There is no conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0).
There is no accumulator variable summing even numbers.
Output describes 'The average acceleration' instead of the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this exercise and a different one (average acceleration), or not carefully reading the current problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment statement and ignore any unrelated template code. Design a new solution that: (1) uses a loop to read exactly 5 integers, (2) for each value, checks if it is even with n % 2 == 0, (3) adds only even numbers to a running sum, and (4) prints the final sum.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
Looping over a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variables, formula, and output message) corresponds to an average-acceleration problem and none of it corresponds to the required task of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: The entire program is structured around reading v0, v1, and t and computing average acceleration, with no loop, no handling of 5 integers, no even-number check, and no sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements

Input mechanism reads only three doubles instead of five integers
